question: What is the difference between `<datalist>` and `<select>` elements? When would you use each?
solution:
```html
<!-- Datalist - provides suggestions but allows custom input -->
<label for="browser">Choose your browser from the list:</label>
<input list="browsers" id="browser" name="browser" placeholder="Type or select...">
<datalist id="browsers">
  <option value="Edge">
  <option value="Firefox">
  <option value="Chrome">
  <option value="Safari">
  <option value="Opera">
</datalist>

<!-- Select - fixed dropdown with predefined options only -->
<label for="cars">Choose a car:</label>
<select id="cars" name="cars">
  <option value="volvo">Volvo</option>
  <option value="saab">Saab</option>
  <option value="mercedes">Mercedes</option>
  <option value="audi">Audi</option>
</select>

<!-- Multiple selection with datalist -->
<label for="skills">Enter your skills:</label>
<input list="skill-options" id="skills" name="skills" multiple>
<datalist id="skill-options">
  <option value="JavaScript">
  <option value="Python">
  <option value="Java">
  <option value="C++">
</datalist>
```

**Key Differences:**

| Feature | `<datalist>` | `<select>` |
|---------|--------------|------------|
| **Input Type** | Text input with suggestions | Dropdown menu |
| **User Input** | Can type custom values | Must choose from predefined options |
| **Flexibility** | High - accepts any input | Low - restricted to options |
| **Use Case** | Search fields, autocomplete | Fixed choices like country, gender |
| **Validation** | Accepts any value | Only accepts listed values |
| **Appearance** | Input field with dropdown hints | Traditional dropdown |

**When to Use:**
- **`<datalist>`**: Search boxes, tags, flexible input with suggestions
- **`<select>`**: Fixed categories, required choices, form validation

Explain the different CSS units (absolute vs relative). When should you use each type?
solution:
CSS units are categorized into **absolute** and **relative** units:

**Absolute Units** (fixed size):
- `px` - Pixels (most common)
- `pt` - Points (1pt = 1/72 inch)
- `cm`, `mm`, `in` - Physical measurements

**Relative Units** (relative to something else):
- `em` - Relative to parent element's font-size
- `rem` - Relative to root element's font-size
- `%` - Relative to parent element
- `vw` - 1% of viewport width
- `vh` - 1% of viewport height
- `vmin/vmax` - Smaller/larger of vw or vh

```css
/* Examples */
.container {
  width: 800px;        /* Absolute - always 800px */
  max-width: 90%;      /* Relative - 90% of parent */
  padding: 2rem;       /* Relative - 2x root font-size */
  margin: 1em;         /* Relative - 1x parent font-size */
}

.hero-section {
  height: 100vh;       /* Full viewport height */
  width: 100vw;        /* Full viewport width */
}

.responsive-font {
  font-size: 4vw;      /* Scales with viewport */
  min-font-size: 16px; /* Minimum size */
}
```

**When to use:**
- **px**: Borders, shadows, precise layouts
- **rem**: Font sizes, spacing (preferred for scalability)
- **em**: Component-based spacing that should scale with local font-size
- **%**: Fluid layouts, responsive widths
- **vw/vh**: Full-screen sections, responsive typography

Does one stylesheet block another from downloading? How do browsers handle multiple CSS files?
solution:
**No, stylesheets do NOT block each other from downloading.** Browsers download multiple CSS files in parallel, but they are processed sequentially and can block rendering.

**How Browser Handles CSS:**

**1. Parallel Download:**
```html
<!-- These download simultaneously */
<link rel="stylesheet" href="style1.css">
<link rel="stylesheet" href="style2.css">
<link rel="stylesheet" href="style3.css">
```

**2. Sequential Processing:**
- Files are applied in the order they appear in HTML
- Later stylesheets can override earlier ones
- All CSS must be parsed before rendering begins

**3. Render Blocking:**
```html
<!-- Blocks rendering until all CSS is loaded */
<head>
  <link rel="stylesheet" href="large-file.css">
```

**Optimization Techniques:**
```html
<!-- Critical CSS inline for faster rendering */
<style>
  /* Critical above-the-fold styles */
  body { font-family: Arial; }
  .header { background: #333; }
</style>

<!-- Non-critical CSS loaded asynchronously */
<link rel="preload" href="non-critical.css" as="style" onload="this.onload=null;this.rel='stylesheet'">

<!-- Media queries for conditional loading */
<link rel="stylesheet" href="print.css" media="print">
<link rel="stylesheet" href="mobile.css" media="(max-width: 768px)">
```

**Best Practices:**
- Minimize CSS files (combine when possible)
- Load critical CSS inline
- Use `preload` for important stylesheets
- Consider conditional loading with media queries
